comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: That's Anna Shaw on the left . . . .

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content:
Whoops, yes, of course.  I'm never good at left-right (don't give me driving directions or ballroom dance classes, it's hopeless).  Should have double-checked myself.

The woman on the left certainly is Anna Shaw!  Now who's on the right?

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: Anna Howard Shaw (February 14, 1847 – July 2, 1919) was a leader of the women's suffrage movement in the United States. She was also a physician and the first ordained female Methodist minister in the United States. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anna_Shaw Florence Jaffray "Daisy" Harriman (July 21, 1870 – August 31, 1967) was an American socialite, suffragist, social reformer, organizer, and later, a courageous diplomat. “She led one of the suffrage parades down Fifth Avenue, worked on campaigns on child labor and safe milk and, as minister to Norway in World War II, organized evacuation efforts while hiding in a forest from the Nazi invasion.” In her ninety-second year, U.S. President John F. Kennedy honored her by awarding her the first “Citation of Merit for Distinguished Service.” She often found herself in the middle of historic events. As she stated, “I think nobody can deny that I have always had through sheer luck. . . a box seat at the America of my times.” Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florence_Jaffray_Harriman The photographer was fooled by the name on the banner she was carrying. Does everyone agree it is Harriman? I recognize her as Harriman, but I can be wrong.

comment.author: 35014516@N03
comment._content: Thanks.  Next time we update the record we'll change the title to give the names of the persons in the picture.
